title: Tweetbot and Twitterrific Face the Cliff

last_post.content:
The fine folks at Tapbots and the Iconfactory need your help.

If you were a subscriber to either Tweetbot or Twitteriffic, please re-install the app and click the button to decline your refund.

It's difficult, perhaps, to understand what a huge impact this would make on these folks, but your effort and small monetary sacrifice will help them more than you know.

More details in Daring Fireball's post: https://daringfireball.net/2023/03/tweetbot_and_twitterrific_face_the_cliff

title: A new study about seabirds and offshore wind turbines may surprise you

last_post.content:
A new study about seabirds and offshore wind turbines may surprise you.

A two-year, €3 million study of seabirds at an offshore wind farm off Scotland combined radar data with cameras to identify the species of seabird and create a three-dimensional image of birds’ flight patterns and how they avoid offshore wind turbines’ rotor blades.

The study’s findings: Not a single collision between a bird and a rotor blade was recorded.

https://electrek.co/2023/03/02/seabirds-and-offshore-wind-turbines-vattenfall/

Comp sci degree
1.5 years as a software test engineer
Python and NodeJS for my relevant experince, but I'm a fast learner and know a few others as well
Same field, full stack web dev, sysadmin, or dev ops stuff is right up my alley
Looking for remote, but can commute (Minneapolis/St. Paul, MN, USA)
I'm a trans woman, so clear acceptance/queer coworkers are a huge plus

Entry level would be best, I don't have enough work experience for most places to look at me mid-level. DM for a resume or any questions, take a look at my site for some examples of things I do!

title: Alaska Says It’s Now Legal “in Some Instances” to Discriminate Against LGBTQ Individuals

last_post.content:
When Alaska rolled back its protections for LGBTQ people, it didn't send out a press release.

Instead, the state quietly announced the policy change via the social media feeds of its human rights commission.

The agency's Twitter and Facebook accounts had a total of 102 followers as of yesterday.

New, from @ProPublica & Anchorage Daily News:

https://www.propublica.org/article/alaska-drops-lgbtq-discrimination-ban?utm_medium=social&utm_source=mastodon&utm_campaign=mastodon-post

last_post.content:
You can tell when an argument hits home by the number of trolls it brings out on social media. When I recommended Thom Hartmann's article linked below two days ago, posting excerpts from it, a number of trolls immediately came out of the woodwork.

Hartmann's argument is essentially one that anyone who takes what happened with Nazi Germany and the Holocaust seriously doesn't dismiss lightly: It can happen here.

title: IPLC Letter to the Office of Science & Technology Policy

last_post.content:
Update. The statement is now on the #HarvardLibrary website.
https://library.harvard.edu/about/news/2023-03-03/iplc-letter-office-science-technology-policy

Another excerpt: "We want to highlight the dangers of allowing the interests of commercial #publishers to dictate the paths available to [#OpenAccess]…We refer here to the…#APC (article processing charge)…and/or institutional #ReadAndPublish agreements where libraries pay bulk APCs on behalf of their scholars and unlock institutional access to read pay-walled content."

title: sciencedirect.com/science/arti...

last_post.content:
I’m a co-author on a new paper out in The Lancet - part of the Lancet Commission’s ongoing work.

It traces the evolving dynamics of the anti-vaccine movement from the “Jenny McCarthy crunchy left” that many remember, to a networked activism movement with strong ties to right-wing identity. It describes the increasing tactical reliance on online harassment as well.

https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0140673623001368

Now that the Pandas 2.0 release candidate is out, I was just taking the new PyArrow backend for a test drive. It's a significant boost over the original NumPy backend.
For string manipulation, it even seems faster than polars.

title: Hugo Reinert (@hugo@assemblag.es)

last_post.content:
I've talked about this in smaller contexts, but I haven't found any traction and time is getting short. When the Nazis passed the enabling laws for the book burning on April 8th, 1933 — exactly 90 years ago in 34 days — the first thing they burnt, the same day, were the archives of the largest trans and gay research institute in the world. When they say now that we didn't exist until after the war, the only reason they can get away with it is that they burned all the accumulated evidence.

https://assemblag.es/@hugo/109972631252644527

title: Toolformer: Language Models Can Teach Themselves to Use Tools

last_post.content:
"In this paper, we show that
LMs can teach themselves to use external tools
via simple APIs and achieve the best of both
worlds.

[...]

This is done in a self-supervised
way, requiring nothing more than a handful of
demonstrations for each API. We incorporate
a range of tools, including a calculator, a Q&A
system, a search engine, a translation system,
and a calendar."

https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.04761

title: Never use a URL shortening service - even if you own it

last_post.content:
some random thoughts on decay of historical twitter data:

* all those old threadreader "unrolls" are gone
* all the storify collections too
* lots of those shortlinks are now broken or point to sites that are scammy, spammy or untrustworthy (c.f. https://shkspr.mobi/blog/2023/02/never-use-a-url-shortening-service-even-if-you-own-it/ )

i don't know if i agree with the above post that there's a high risk of this being used for evil, but it's pretty easy to search your twitter data and delete, say, all gu dot com links en masse

title: The Next Deadly Pandemic Is Just a Forest Clearing Away

last_post.content: "The next deadly pandemic is just a forest clearing away. But we’re not even trying to prevent it." https://www.propublica.org/article/pandemic-spillover-outbreak-guinea-forest-clearing "Models have shown that the more patchy a forest gets, the more edges are created at the borders of clearings where virus-carrying animals can come into contact with humans, until so much forest is cut down that it can’t sustain wildlife anymore. The theoretical model encapsulates this concept to assess risk by considering the amount of “edge” produced by deforestation"

last_post.content:

title: gofundme.com/f/help-fox-and-ze...

last_post.content: Being trans online is watching everyone else have to do crowdfunding until you're the one doing it, and it's my turn. This is a moving fund one of my friends set up for me. WHAT THIS WILL ALLOW ME TO DO: Move out of the Bay Area, which has no housing mobility, and is an increasingly-untenable living situation. Moving to Philly will allow me to get better healthcare as a trans person, move in with my partner, and be in proximity to a support network. https://www.gofundme.com/f/help-fox-and-zelda-move-in-together

title: The implications of Walgreens' decision on abortion pills

last_post.content: Walgreens will never get another dollar of my money. Its refusal to sell a vital, legal product is disgusting. If CVS goes along with this, the pharmacy cartel will be lending its considerable weight to a policy that the vast majority of Americans reject -- a policy mandated by a minority party of extremists. https://abcnews.go.com/Health/wireStory/implications-walgreens-decision-abortion-pills-97617141

title: Let Wikipedia Be Your Guide With Non-Sketchy News Search (NSNS) - ResearchBuzz Search Gizmos

last_post.content:
I've been trying to crack the problem of crappy #Google #news #search. After lots of trying I've made a solution I quite like: Non-Sketchy News Search.

It uses keyword searching of #Wikipedia to find media categories, then lets you choose outlets from a category to include in a Google search (using site:)

Give it a try. It's free, no ads except for Patreon banner.

*Might not work on your phone, I only code on desktop.*

https://searchgizmos.com/nsns/

title: https://blahaj.zone/tags/trans

last_post.content:
I want the cis people in my followers list to see this.

Just this weekend, in the US, at the Conservative Political Action Conference, one of the speakers at the event called for the eradication of trans people from daily life.

Eradication. There were no euphemisms, just an outright call for genocide.

That is where we are heading.

Australia is lucky. We aren't as far down that pipeline as the US, but we are going that way.

The trans people in your life are terrified. We need your help, we need your voices. This isn't a theoretical issue, or a future issue. It's right here, and it's right now.

Help us

#trans #transgender #uspol #pol #auspol

RE: https://mastodon.scot/users/juliegrrl/statuses/109969417427093667

title: Writing - Foundations - Human Interface Guidelines - Design - Apple Developer

last_post.content:
Loved the Apple HIG "Writing" guide: https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/foundations/writing/

Via @stern: https://mastodon.social/@stern/109961894927064285

Anyone who writes text for UIs should read that.

And it linked to something even better, Apple's guide to inclusive writing, that *everyone* should read: https://support.apple.com/guide/applestyleguide/intro-apdcb2a65d68/web

The craft of making great apps depends SO MUCH on good writing.

title: LastPass says employee’s home computer was hacked and corporate vault taken

last_post.content:
As advised previously, all LastPass users should change their master passwords and all passwords stored in their vaults, because while it’s not clear whether the threat actor has access to either, the precautions are certainly warranted.
https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2023/02/lastpass-hackers-infected-employees-home-computer-and-stole-corporate-vault/?utm_brand=ars

title: GitHub - timhutton/twitter-archive-parser: Python code to parse a Twitter archive and output in various ways

last_post.content: btw, if you downloaded your twitter data, all links are shortened with t dot co, meaning they can't be expanded without visiting twitter. i used this tool to go through and fix them all so i know what was originally linked: https://github.com/timhutton/twitter-archive-parser

title: Introducing Signals – Preact

last_post.content:
“Introducing Signals” by @marvinh and @developit is very much worth reading as a web developer, whether you’re using Preact or not. Great explanation of the complexity in current state management, with an elegant and framework-agnostic alternative.

https://preactjs.com/blog/introducing-signals/

#webdev #javascript

title: "Transgenderism should be eradicated from public life, entirely."

last_post.content:
#transphobia #genocide #cpac #recycled_nazism

85 years ago, under the German Nazi regime, the Institute of Forensic Medicine recommended that the “phenomena of transvestism” be “exterminated from public life.”

A few days ago US conservative Michael Knowles said, live streamed from the CPAC 2023 conference in the USA, that “transgenderism must be eliminated from public life entirely,” in an eerie, almost word-for-word, echo of Nazi Germany.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-rs2_q-AUGU

title: Florida bills would ban gender studies, transgender pronouns, tenure perks

last_post.content:
Matcha smoothies and foosball tables at the office are perks, WaPo. Tenure is not a perk. Tenure protects the academic freedom of professors from fascists like Ron DeSantis and his fellow thought police in the GOP.

Florida bills would ban gender studies, transgender pronouns, tenure perks

https://www.washingtonpost.com/education/2023/03/05/florida-bills-would-ban-gender-studies-transgender-pronouns-tenure-perks/

title: Gwyneth Windflower

last_post.content:
i wrote a short article about what’s changing in the data ecosystem, and how metaphors can help us think about it. particularly how data is becoming less like a glacier we need to carve ice from and more like a vibrant watershed we can nurture.

let me know what you think, i hope it ignites some sparks of imagination about the coming developments in the data space.

https://www.gwenwindflower.com/blog/2

title: Fighting reviewer fatigue or amplifying bias? Considerations and recommendations for use of ChatGPT and other Large Language Models in scholarly peer review

last_post.content:
Good start on a hard question — how or whether to use #AI tools in #PeerReview.
https://www.researchsquare.com/article/rs-2587766/v1

"For the moment, we recommend that if #LLMs are used to write scholarly reviews, reviewers should disclose their use and accept full responsibility for their reports’ accuracy, tone, reasoning and originality."

PS: "For the moment" these tools can help reviewers string words together, not judge quality. We have good reasons to seek evaluative comments from human experts.
